content.title: Theoretical Minimum Angular Momentum
content.abstract: Angular momentum is quantized in units of ℏ/2, making this one of the most fundamental and well-established quantizations in physics, directly following from the algebraic structure of quantum mechanics.

quantization_rule.z_component: J_z = mℏ where m = -j, -j+1, ..., j-1, j

types_of_angular_momentum.quantization: j can be integer or half-integer depending on spin

why_half_integers.explanation: Single-valuedness under 4π rotation (not 2π) allows half-integer representations

physical_implications.description: Half-integer spin → fermions (Pauli exclusion), integer spin → bosons
Electron spin ℏ/2 underlies periodic table via Pauli principle
Spin angular momentum creates intrinsic magnetic dipole
Direct observation of spin-1/2 quantization (two spots)

can_angular_momentum_be_zero.answer: Yes, for spinless particles and l=0 states
examples: Ground state hydrogen atom has l=0 (but electron still has spin)
can_angular_momentum_be_zero.note: For massive particles with spin, intrinsic spin is always nonzero

comparison_with_planck.relation: Minimum nonzero spin = ℏ/2 = half of Planck angular momentum
comparison_with_planck.insight: Planck constant IS the quantum of angular momentum (orbital) or action
